questions.text: A 15-day-old baby presents with frequent vomiting after starting breast milk. After symptom resolution, he returns with jaundice and hepatosplenomegaly. Ocular findings are noted. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Galactosemia 

The cataract shown is an Oil Drop Cataract, which is characteristic of Galactosemia. Condition: Classic galactosemia  Enzyme Deficiency: Galactose-1-phosphate uridylyltransferase  Pathophysiology: Accumulation of toxic substances, such as galactitol

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is being evaluated for frequent falls and recurrent sino-pulmonary infections. The image below shows the ocular findings. What is the likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Defective homologous repair                                    

The given clinical scenario describes a case of ataxia-telangiectasia, which is due to a defective homologous repair of DNA.

This child who has frequent falls (gait disturbances), characteristic ocular telangiectasia (soen in the Image), and immunodeficiency(recurrent sinopulmonary infections) has ataxia-telangiectasia. It is an autosomal recessive disorder due to defect is in the ATM gene localized to chromosome 11.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents with features of angular stomatitis and a magenta tongue. Deficiency of which of the following vitamin will result in the above features?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Vitamin B2

In the given clinical scenario presence of angular stomatitis and magenta tongue is suggestive of vitamin B2/riboflavin deficiency.

questions.text: Which of the following is not inherited in an shown inheritance pattern?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Erythropoietic protoporphyria

Erythropoietic protoporphyria is not transmitted in an autosomal dominant manner. It is an autosomal recessive disease. It is caused due to a defect in the enzyme ferrochelatase (FECH). It is the most common porphyria in children. Non-blistering photosensitivity is present.

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child being assessed at a primary health center presents with severely disfigured lips from habitual biting, difficulty walking, dystonia, spasticity, and choreoathetosis. He has been diagnosed with a lack of the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase. The condition he most likely has is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.  

This child is most likely suffering from Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, which is an X-linked genetic disorder resulting from a complete deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT).

questions.text: A 1-year-old baby was brought by his mother with growth failure and developmental delay. Laboratory investigations revealed a hemoglobin of 8 g/dL and normal levels of vitamin B12 and B9. His peripheral smear is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Orotic aciduria 

The above clinical scenario with a peripheral smear showing hypersegmented neutrophils with normal vitamin B12 and B9 levels is suggestive of orotic aciduria.

Orotic aciduria is a rare autosomal recessive condition. It occurs due to an error in the de novo synthesis of pyrimidine resulting in the failure of conversion of orotic acid to uridine. As a result, there is increased excretion of orotic acid in urine. It is of two types:

•	Type I-deficiency of both orotate phosphoribosyl transferase and OMP decarboxylase (together called UMPsynthase)

•	Type II deficiency of only orotidylate decarboxylase.

questions.text: Which of the following lipid storage disorder has maximum predilection to present with shown finding on Macula?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Tay Sach's disease

The correct answer regarding the lipid storage disorder that has the maximum predilection to present with a Cherry Red Spot in the Macula is Tay-Sachs disease. 

Tay-Sachs disease is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme hexosaminidase A, leading to the accumulation of GM2 gangliosides in neurons. Ocular findings in Tay-Sachs disease can include a Cherry Red Spot at the macula, which is due to the storage of lipids in the ganglion cells of the retina.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamin deficiency must have led to this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Nicotinamide

Pellagra is a condition caused by niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency. It is characterized by the "3 Ds": dermatitis (skin rash), diarrhea, and dementia (mental changes). Niacin deficiency can occur due to inadequate dietary intake of niacin or tryptophan, a precursor of niacin.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male with generalized weakness, loss of appetite, and shown finding of bilateral ankle after walking a mile presents with a 15-year history of alcoholism and a diet primarily of polished rice. Workup indicates a vitamin deficiency. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Beri Beri

The most likely diagnosis in this case is Beri Beri.

Beri Beri is caused by thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency. Chronic alcoholism can lead to poor nutrition and impaired absorption of thiamine, contributing to the development of Beri Beri. The symptoms typically include weakness, loss of appetite, peripheral edema (swelling around ankles), and cardiovascular manifestations such as tachycardia and high output heart failure.

questions.text: A 40-year-old sedentary female executive presents with shown findings and X-ray showing calcified intervertebral discs. Urine tests with Benedict's reagent yield a greenish-brown precipitate. What is the likely enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Homogentisic acid oxidase

The most likely enzyme deficiency in this patient is homogentisic acid oxidase. The symptoms described, including palmoplantar pigmentation, calcification of intervertebral discs, and a positive Benedict's test with a greenish-brown precipitate, are characteristic of alkaptonuria. Alkaptonuria is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme homogentisic acid oxidase, leading to the accumulation of homogentisic acid.

questions.text: A baby is being evaluated for delayed developmental milestones. On examination, the child has hepatosplenomegaly. A microscopic image of the bone marrow evaluation is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Gaucher disease

The microscopic image of the bone marrow biopsy shows Gaucher cells and the diagnosis is Gaucher disease. Gaucher disease is a lysosomal storage disease with autosomal recessive inheritance. The condition results due to the deficiency of acid ẞ-glucosidase. This results in the accumulation of glucosylceramide (a glycolipid substrate) in the reticuloendothelial cells. There is progressive infiltration of the liver, spleen, and bone marrow.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents with recurring fevers, fatigue, joint pain, a butterfly rash, mouth sores, easy bruising, and heightened anxiety and depression. A diagnostic blood test will likely reveal autoimmune antibodies targeting which class of molecules?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Ribonuclear protein complexes. 

The woman has lupus, an autoimmune disorder. One class of antibodies developed is against the snurps, small ribonuclear protein complexes, which are involved in mRNA splicing. Autoantibodies are not developed against DNA polymerase (although antibodies against DNA are often found), carbohydrates, tRNA complexes, or peroxisomal proteins.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman has developed dark, smooth, velvety patches on her neck and in her armpits. What is the molecular basis of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Persistently inhibited insulin  receptors. 

The patient has acanthosis nigricans, which results from insulin resistance. One way in which insulin resistance can be obtained is through a persistent inhibition of insulin receptor activity. Alterations in the glucagon, EGF, or thyroid hormone receptors will not lead to insulin resistance.

questions.text: A newborn has milky white skin, white hair, and redappearing eye color as shown. This disorder most often results from a defect in which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Tyrosinase

The child has albinism, marked by a lack of skin pigment due to defective melanocyte tyrosinase (distinct from neuronal tyrosinase, which produces DOPA for catecholamines). DOPA is crucial for pigment production. Phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency causes PKU, while a lack of dihydrofolate reductase is likely lethal. Tetrahydrofolate is not required for converting tyrosine to DOPA in melanocytes. NADPH oxidase produces superoxide, unrelated to this pathway. Homogentisic acid is part of phenylalanine and tyrosine degradation, not albinism

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy presents with a large abdomen, splenomegaly, fatigue, anemia, thrombocytopenia, and easy bruising. X-rays reveal a deformity of the distal femur. This disorder is caused by an accumulation of which substance in macrophage lysosomes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Glucosylceramide 

The child has Gaucher disease, caused by a glucosidase defect that prevents the breakdown of glucosylceramide, leading to glucosylcerebroside accumulation in lysosomes. This results in symptoms including hepatomegaly and splenomegaly. In contrast, Krabbe disease results from galactosylceramide degradation issues but does not cause hepatomegaly or splenomegaly. Other lysosomal storage disorders, such as Niemann-Pick, metachromatic leukodystrophy, and Farber disease, involve different defects and symptoms.

questions.text: An 8-month-old infant presents with jaundice, lethargy, and splenomegaly. Blood tests show microcytic anemia with abnormal erythrocytes. This condition is likely caused by a hereditary mutation in which gene?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Spectrin

The child is exhibiting the symptoms of hereditary spherocytosis, a defect in spectrin in the erythrocyte membrane. This membrane problem leads to an abnormal shape of the red blood cell, such that the spleen removes them from circulation (hence, the large spleen), leading to an anemia due to a reduction of red blood cells in circulation.

questions.text: In a patient who has experienced prolonged starvation, which of the following tests would yield positive results when conducted on their urine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Rothera's test

Rothera's test is done for the detection of ketone bodies which are produced as a result of starvation/fasting. The purple color ring at the junction of 2 liquids is a positive test. Given positive by acetoacetate and acetone.

questions.text: The image shows Pyruvate Dehydrogenase Complex. What is E1 and E2 ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Pyruvate dehydrogenase, Dihydrolipoyl Acetyl transferase 

E1 : Pyruvate dehydrogenase, E2: Dihydrolipoyl Acetyl transferase Inside the mitochondria, pyruvate is oxidatively decarboxylated to acetyl CoA by pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH).

questions.text: Identify the etiology of chromosomal pattern shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Prader Willi syndrome 

Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS) is a rare genetic disorder resulting from the loss of function of specific genes on chromosome 15. In newborns, symptoms typically include weak muscle tone, difficulties with feeding, and delayed development. As children grow, they often experience an insatiable appetite, which can lead to obesity and an increased risk of type 2 diabetes. Additionally, individuals with PWS frequently exhibit mild to moderate intellectual disabilities and various behavioral challenges. Common physical characteristics include a narrow forehead, small hands and feet, shorter stature, and lighter skin and hair. Most individuals with this condition are infertile.

questions.text: A baby is being evaluated for delayed developmental milestones. On examination, there is hepatosplenomegaly. A microscopic image of the bone marrow evaluation is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Option A - Gaucher disease: Gaucher disease is a rare genetic disorder caused by a deficiency in an enzyme called glucocerebrosidase, which leads to an accumulation of a fatty substance called glucocerebroside in the cells of the body, particularly in the spleen, liver, and bone marrow. • The accumulation of this substance causes hepatosplenomegaly (enlargement of the liver and spleen), anemia, fatigue, and bone pain. • On microscopic examination of bone marrow, the presence of Gaucher cells, which are lipid-laden macrophages with a wrinkled-paper appearance, is a characteristic finding.
